elements.content: Molecular simulations have been widely employed in the discovery of nanoporous materials, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and zeolite, for energy- and environment-related applications. To achieve simulation predictions with better accuracy, we herein present a collection of molecular models, including carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), carbonyl sulfide (COS), hydrogen sulfide (H2S), nitrogen (N2), nitrous oxide (N2O), and sulfur dioxide (SO2). These models, denoted as electrostatic potential optimized molecular models (ESP-MMs), are systematically developed to not only reproduce experimental vapor–liquid equilibrium but also have accurate electrostatic potential representation surrounding the molecules. Our results show that, with accurate electrostatic potential representations, ESP-MMs can offer improved predictions in a variety of adsorption properties for porous materials, including MOFs with open-metal sites and all-silica zeolites. Specifically, by using ESP-MMs, the binding geometry and adsorption energy landscape can be well captured. This enables these models to be employed to unravel the fundamental mechanism of gaseous adsorption in materials of interest as well as to facilitate the parametrization of adsorbent–adsorbate interactions. We also demonstrate that, combined with generic force fields for adsorbents, ESP-MMs can offer reasonable predictions in adsorption isotherms. Although these ESP-MMs use a relatively simple and nonpolarizable potential form for the sake of efficiency and applicability, their accuracy has been extensively validated in this study. Furthermore, the set of Lennard-Jones potentials with static point charges adopted for ESP-MMs can be readily implemented in all available simulation packages. We anticipate that these ESP-MMs can largely facilitate future computational studies of porous materials for gas separation and removal.

elements.content: Nanoporous materials, such as zeolites or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have gained tremendous attention for their potential in a wide variety of energy- and environment-related processes. These materials are especially advantageous as adsorbents or membranes in the removal, separation, or storage of various gas molecules, which can be attributed to many of their desirable properties such as their large surface area, low heat capacity, and selective adsorption or transport of one molecule over another. Another important feature is their chemical and structural diversity. For instance, ∼230 IZA (International Zeolite Association) zeolites have been reported to date, while more than 100 000 hypothetical topologies were predicted. Furthermore, tens of thousands of MOFs have been reported and more than hundreds of thousands of MOFs can be hypothetically synthesized. While such a large library of nanoporous materials provides great opportunities, it also imposes significant challenges in the search of optimal structures. To this end, computational methods can help facilitate the materials discovery and design. One commonly employed tool is quantum mechanical (QM) method. Despite high accuracy, however, the expensive QM calculations make it prohibitive to study systems such as adsorption or diffusion of gas molecules in nanoporous materials that require a significant amount of computational resources. For this reason, classical molecular simulations such as Monte Carlo (MC) or molecular dynamics (MD) have been widely adopted to compute thermodynamic and kinetic properties. In these calculations, interactions between molecules or between the molecule and the framework are described by some mathematical functions, which are referred to as force fields (FFs) or potentials. As gaseous adsorption and diffusion properties largely pertain to the molecular interactions, reliability of the simulation predictions greatly depends on the accuracy of the FFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Nanoporous materials, such as zeolites
or metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), have gained tremendous attention for their potential
in a wide variety of energy- and environment-related processes. These materials are especially advantageous as adsorbents or membranes
in the removal, separation, or storage of various gas molecules, which
can be attributed to many of their desirable properties such as their
large surface area, low heat capacity, and selective adsorption or
transport of one molecule over another. Another important feature is their chemical and structural diversity.
For instance, ∼230 IZA (International Zeolite Association)
zeolites have been reported to date, while
more than 100 000 hypothetical topologies were predicted. Furthermore, tens of thousands of MOFs have been reported and more
than hundreds of thousands of MOFs can be hypothetically synthesized. While such a large library of nanoporous materials provides great
opportunities, it also imposes significant challenges in the search
of optimal structures. To this end, computational methods can help
facilitate the materials discovery and design. One commonly employed
tool is quantum mechanical (QM) method. Despite high accuracy, however,
the expensive QM calculations make it prohibitive to study systems
such as adsorption or diffusion of gas molecules in nanoporous materials
that require a significant amount of computational resources. For
this reason, classical molecular simulations such as Monte Carlo (MC)
or molecular dynamics (MD) have been widely adopted to compute thermodynamic
and kinetic properties. In these calculations, interactions between
molecules or between the molecule and the framework are described
by some mathematical functions, which are referred to as force fields
(FFs) or potentials. As gaseous adsorption and diffusion properties
largely pertain to the molecular interactions, reliability of the
simulation predictions greatly depends on the accuracy of the FFs.

elements.content: For accurate molecule–molecule interactions, many previous molecular models were developed with a particular focus on reproducing the experimental vapor–liquid equilibrium (VLE). For the interaction between the molecule and the framework, on the other hand, several methodologies were proposed. Specifically, recent studies focused on parametrizing the adsorbate–adsorbent dispersion (i.e., van der Waals (vdW)) parameters to reproduce the interaction energy computed from accurate QM methods. Additional potential terms other than the classical Coulombic and vdW interaction contributions were also considered to describe adsorbate–adsorbent interactions. For all the methods proposed for molecule–molecule or molecule–framework interactions, a general assumption is that the adopted molecular model is able to accurately describe the electronic distribution and thus the electrostatic interaction between the molecules or between the molecule and the framework. This however may not be always the case.

elements.content: We recently proposed a systematic and robust methodology for molecular model development that ensures accuracy in the charge distributions of the models. This was achieved by systematically optimizing the number of massless sites included in the molecular model with their location and the charge assignments to reproduce the electrostatic potential (ESP) surrounding the molecule computed with accurate QM methods. As a proof of concept, we applied the methodology to hydrogen sulfide (H2S) molecular models and showed that the developed models have improved accuracy in reproducing both adsorption and bulk liquid properties. Given the success, we herein extend this methodology to several other molecules, including carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), carbonyl sulfide (COS), nitrogen (N2), nitrous oxide (N2O), and sulfur dioxide (SO2). The removal or storage of these molecules is critically important in energy related or environmentally related processes. For instance, CO is formed from an incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials, and its removal is essential as the inhalation of CO may cause diseases such as those related to the cardiovascular system. Acidic molecules such as CO2 or SO2 are also known for their negative effects on the environment. It should be noted that, different from the originally proposed methodology, two global scaling factors are introduced in the parametrization of dispersion parameters for molecules with heterogeneous atoms, and this updated approach is also employed to reparametrize the molecular models for H2S. Overall, as will be described below in detail for the development of these models, their geometry is first optimized with density functional theory (DFT) calculations and the ESP surrounding the molecule is simultaneously obtained. Subsequently, the number of massless sites, the location of massless sites, and the point charge assignments are optimized by reproducing the DFT-computed ESP. Lastly, with an accurate ESP representation, the vdW interaction parameters are optimized to fit to the VLE curve. For molecules with heterogeneous atom types (e.g., CO) that can have four or more vdW interaction parameters, we introduce global scaling factors, one for the epsilon (ε) and the other one for the sigma (σ) of the Lennard-Jones potential, to significantly reduce the parameter space.

elements.content: In the following, we first summarize our methodology. In , we introduce the developed molecular models, denoted as electrostatic potential optimized molecular models (ESP-MMs), for all of the above-mentioned molecules. The developed CO model is then discussed in detail as a case study, and the importance of the number and location of the massless site is thoroughly explored. We show that the CO model with reliable charge distributions can accurately identify the binding mechanism of CO adsorbed in open-metal-site MOF-74 materials and Cu-BTC. We then take a step forward to demonstrate the preferential importance of the ESP by showing that extreme values of Lennard-Jones parameters do not affect the binding orientation provided an accurate ESP representation. The experimental adsorption isotherm of CO in Cu-BTC and all-silica MFI can also be reasonably reproduced with the ESP-MM. Comparisons with previously developed CO models are included as well. For the rest of the molecular models, we verify their accuracy in predicting their binding geometry in MOF-74. The adsorption isotherm of SO2 in all-silica MFI is also computed and compared with experimental measurements. Lastly, we demonstrate the high fidelity of the charge distributions described by these ESP-MMs as their charges are determined to remain nearly identical when molecules are clustered in a dimer configuration.

Methodology

procedure for the molecular model development is described
in this section, which involves three steps: (1) , (2) , and (3) . More details can be

elements.content: The number and location of massless sites and the assigned point charges are optimized by reproducing the DFT-computed ESP. Although nonperiodic DFT calculations or other high-level quantum mechanics methods (e.g., MP2) can be employed for obtaining the ESP of isolated molecules and subsequently determining their charges, we adopt the same method implemented in periodic DFT as that of the charge determination adopted for the framework atoms. In molecular simulations, it is preferred to employ molecular models with a smaller number of massless sites included for computational efficiency. For this reason, the model development starts with the lowest possible number of massless sites (i.e., from zero, one, etc.). For each included number of massless sites, their location is explored in a grid-search manner. For each grid point, the point charges of the model that can best reproduce the DFT-computed ESP are obtained with the REPEAT scheme. The deviations in the ESP computed by the assigned point charges relative to that by DFT are quantified by an objective function, i.e., the relative root-mean-square (RRMS) value. The location of the massless sites with the lowest RRMS value is chosen as the optimum. If the lowest RRMS value is not sufficiently low enough for a given included number of massless sites, the number of massless sites is successively increased until a satisfactory ESP representation is achieved. We note that, for some molecular models, the search space of the massless sites is constrained in order to maintain the symmetry of the molecule. For instance, one additional massless site for the CO molecule can only be assigned to along the CO bond vector. It should be also noted that, while the grid-search approach has been found to be an adequate method to develop models for molecules studied in this work, a variety of advanced optimization algorithms can be implemented to further enable a more efficient determination of the number and location of massless sites for more complex molecules.

elements.content: Based on the well-established Dreiding force field, the two scaling factors are applied to scale the parameters from Dreiding and optimized to reproduce experimental VLE. For each combination of the scaling factors, VLE data over an extensive temperature range are computed by the Gibbs ensemble Monte Carlo (GEMC) technique. The ones with the least error as compared to the experimental values are chosen as the final L-J parameters. The corresponding critical temperature and density are also calculated using the scaling law and the law of rectilinear diameters, respectively, and compared with experimental data.

Based on the well-established Dreiding
force field, the two scaling factors
are applied to scale the parameters from Dreiding and optimized to
reproduce experimental VLE. For each combination of the scaling factors,
VLE data over an extensive temperature range are computed by the Gibbs
ensemble Monte Carlo (GEMC) technique. The ones with the least error
as compared to the experimental values are chosen as the final L-J
parameters. The corresponding critical temperature and density are
also calculated using the scaling law and the law of rectilinear diameters, respectively, and compared with experimental data.

We adopted force field parameters for the framework atoms from the literature. More computational details can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: With the extended methodology as described above, we develop molecular models for CO, CO2, COS, H2S, N2, N2O, and SO2. The geometries of these ESP optimized molecular models (ESP-MMs) with the optimal locations of the massless sites if applicable are shown in . The corresponding point charges and Lennard-Jones (L-J) parameters are summarized in and , respectively. For some of these models, massless sites are required in order to achieve a better representation of the ESP surrounding the molecule (e.g., CO, COS, N2, and SO2 possess one massless site and H2S two massless sites). We note that the location of massless sites and the charge assignment for H2S are adopted from our prior study directly (i.e., 5S-a model, see ref ), but with the L-J parameters being reparametrized. The RRMS value of each optimized model can be also seen in . For each ESP-MM developed herein, the RRMS value is lower than 20%, an indicative of a sufficiently accurate ESP representation. This study proposes for the very first time, to the best of our knowledge, a collection of molecular models that are developed to ensure accuracy in reproducing the ESP representation and the VLE curve in a systematic and efficient manner. We note that while there are some molecular models reported in the literature, such as that of TraPPE CO2 or N2 models, that have been successfully implemented in many of the molecular simulation studies, we still include these molecules in the development using our proposed methodology with the aim of offering a consistent and complete set of molecule models. Interestingly, for CO2 and N2 molecules, the point charges assigned following our methodology are very similar to the TraPPE models (e.g., −0.3253 vs −0.35 for the oxygen atoms of CO2).

elements.content: In the following, we primarily focus on the development of the CO model and its validations in detail as an example. To offer comprehensive analysis, we also compare with other available CO models. There have been various molecular models for CO reported in the literature. Sirjoosingh et al. reported a two-sites model, where the charges are obtained by Mulliken analysis and the L-J parameters are from UFF. Piper et al. proposed a four-sites model with the point charges fitted to reproduce the multipole moments. A three-sites model was suggested by Straub and Karplus with the massless site assigned to the center of mass (COM) and the point charges optimized to reproduce the experimental quadrupole moment. Similarly, a three-sites model reported by Martín-Calvo et al. has the same molecular geometry and the location of massless site as that of Staub and Karplus, but with the point charges optimized by reproducing the experimental dipole moment and with the L-J parameters optimized by reproducing the experimental VLE curve. It should be noted that the model of Martín-Calvo et al. has the same ratio of the point charges and the L-J parameters among each site as that of the Straub and Karplus. For these models, accurate representation of the ESP surrounding the molecule was undervalued, and not all of the model parameters were systematically included in the optimization.

been various molecular models for CO reported in the literature. Sirjoosingh
et al. reported a two-sites model, where the charges are obtained
by Mulliken analysis and the L-J parameters are from UFF. Piper et al. proposed a four-sites model with
the point charges fitted to reproduce the multipole moments. A three-sites model was suggested by Straub
and Karplus with the massless site assigned to the center of mass
(COM) and the point charges optimized to reproduce the experimental
quadrupole moment. Similarly, a three-sites
model reported by Martín-Calvo et al. has the same molecular
geometry and the location of massless site as that of Staub and Karplus, but with the point charges optimized by reproducing
the experimental dipole moment and with the L-J parameters optimized
by reproducing the experimental VLE curve. It should be noted that
the model of Martín-Calvo et al. has the same ratio of the
point charges and the L-J parameters among each site as that of the
Straub and Karplus. For these models, accurate representation of the
ESP surrounding the molecule was undervalued, and not all of the model
parameters were systematically included in the optimization.

elements.content: For the development of the ESP-MM for CO, we start from zero massless sites (i.e., two-sites model), which yields a model with a large RRMS value of 95%. Per the methodology, an additional massless site is subsequently included (i.e., three-sites model), which can significantly lower the RRMS value to 13.9%. Interestingly, the optimal massless site is located outside of the C–O bond and near the carbon atom as shown in a. As a comparison, if we fix the location of the massless site at the center of mass (COM) of the CO molecule, a location that has been widely used in the currently available models as discussed above, the lowest RRMS (i.e., the best possible ESP description) that can be achieved is approximately 30%. The corresponding model is denoted as the CO­(COM) model hereafter. To visualize the ESP representation, shows the ESP surface (or the topology of the ESP field) exerted by the CO molecule, computed by DFT and by molecular models.

elements.content: It can be evidently seen that the ESP by the two-sites model (b) significantly deviates from the DFT-computed one (a), which can be instead well described by our developed three-sites ESP-MM (c). Interestingly, while the ESP of the CO­(COM) model (d) seemingly resembles the DFT-computed one reasonably well, assigning the massless site at the COM fails to accurately describe the ESP near the carbon and oxygen atoms of the CO molecule. For a clear presentation, parts e and f, respectively, of demonstrate the error in the ESP description relative to DFT for the optimized three-sites model and the CO­(COM) model. While a minor error is found for our developed three-sites model, the COM model notably overestimates the ESP near the carbon atom (i.e., too positive) and underestimates the ESP surrounding the oxygen atom (i.e., too negative). We also show the ESP represented by previously developed CO molecular models that can reproduce experimental VLE data in Figure S3 with the corresponding RRMS error provided.

elements.content: With the optimized number and location of massless sites and the corresponding point charges, the L-J parameters of the models are subsequently determined by reproducing the experimental VLE. To reduce the overall parameter space as noted above, based on the assumption that the relative magnitude in the L-J parameters of generic FFs are accurate, two global scaling factors are applied (one for ε and the other for σ) and optimized. Specifically, as noted above, the initial L-J parameters from Dreiding are adopted herein for its popularity in the literature. The VLE curve computed with the CO ESP-MM can be seen in , which well reproduces the experimental VLE as well as the critical temperature and pressure reported from NIST. The L-J parameters for the CO­(COM) model are also optimized (see Figure S4 for its VLE curve), and the obtained parameters as given in Table S1 are very similar to those of the CO ESP-MM model. The same procedures are carried out for the rest of the models for CO2, COS, H2S, N2, N2O, and SO2. Similarly, Figures S5–S10 show that all these ESP-MMs can resemble experimental VLEs accurately. Interestingly, we find that, by using such a scaling approach, only one optimal set of scaling factors is identified for each case. By contrast, if all parameters are fitted for molecules with heterogeneous atoms, multiple optimal L-J parameter combinations are found and each of them can equally accurately reproduce the VLE curve.

elements.content: To validate the developed CO ESP-MM, adsorption properties of CO in various nanoporous materials are computed, with specific emphasis on open-metal-site structures that provide high affinity toward molecules that possess dipole or quadrupole moments. In these structures, electrostatic interactions may play an important role in determining adsorption properties. First, we compute the binding configuration of CO in Mg-MOF-74, a material that has been extensively studied both experimentally and computationally. From previous DFT or experimental studies, CO binds to the Mg-MOF-74 in a way where the carbon atom is closer to the open-metal site than the oxygen atom (i.e., “Mg–C–O” configuration) as shown in a. With our ESP-MM, b shows that models with accurate ESPs are indeed also able to correctly describe the binding mechanism, with a “Mg–C–O” configuration. By contrast, an opposite configuration of CO (i.e., “Mg–O–C” configuration) is predicted with the CO­(COM) model or previous CO models reported in the literature (i.e., models by Sirjoosingh et al. and Martín-Calvo et al.) as shown in c. Provided that the L-J parameters assigned to the CO ESP-MM and the CO­(COM) model are nearly identical, this flipped configuration predicted with the CO­(COM) model can be attributed to the insufficient ESP representation. As discussed above and shown in f, the CO­(COM) model presents overprediction and under prediction of the ESP near the carbon atom and the oxygen atom, respectively, as a result of the location of the massless site being designated to the center of mass rather than being included in the optimization. Although both the CO ESP-MM and the CO­(COM) model are developed by reproducing the VLE (i.e., configurations occurred in the liquid/gas phase), by including electronic structure calculations in the model development to ensure accurate ESP representations, the ESP-MM can also offer more accurate predictions in the spatial configuration of the adsorbed molecules.

elements.content: We also compute the binding energy using the developed CO ESP-MM. An underestimation in binding energy as compared to that predicted by DFT from Lee et al. is observed (∼28 vs 39 kJ/mol). This is in fact expected as many previous studies reported in the literature have found that the use of L-J potential with parameters from generic FFs for open-metal-site structures may lead to too-repulsive interactions, which accordingly underestimates the host–guest (i.e., adsorbent−adsorbate) interaction energy. Parametrizing the host–guest interaction for better describing the non-Coulombic contribution of the interactions between the adsorbent and the adsorbate, particularly in open-metal-site structures, has therefore been an active research area. While parametrizing the adsorbent–adsorbate non-Coulombic interaction is out of the scope of this study, it is important to note that having an accurate molecular model that can ensure accurate description of the Coulombic part such as ESP-MMs is essential in such parametrization. These developed ESP-MMs can ensure that the Coulombic interaction between the framework of interest and the guest molecule can be more accurately described, such that additional corrections will not be included in the fitted non-Coulombic contribution of the parametrized potential. Given the host–guest interactions for open-site MOFs are not specifically optimized, to better validate our models with the DFT-computed energies, relative energies between the two different adsorption states (i.e., “Mg–C–O” and “Mg–O–C”) are compared and summarized in a. Details about these calculations can be found in the Supporting Information. a shows our CO ESP-MM can compute the relative energies accurately, whereas the CO­(COM) model or previously developed models of CO predict, as anticipated, an opposite binding behavior. To further compare the behavior of CO ESP-MM relative to others, multiple CO adsorption configurations are generated by rotating a carbon monoxide molecule near the open-metal site to probe their description in the energy landscape. Specifically, the angle between the C–O vector of CO molecule and the normal vector of the plane generated with four oxygens connected to the Mg is varied (see Figure S1 for a schematic illustration). b shows the interaction energy between the CO and the adsorbent for these configurations computed with DFT and models of the CO ESP-MM and those by Sirjoosingh et al. and Martín-Calvo et al., and the CO ESP-MM is able to follow the same trend in the energy as that predicted by DFT. While the overpredictions in the energy with CO ESP-MM are expected as discussed above, the difference is consistent throughout different configurations.

elements.content: To investigate the effect of L-J parameters, we also develop CO models with the geometry and point charges the same as that of the CO ESP-MM but based on different initial L-J parameters. Specifically, we adopt L-J parameters from UFF, another widely used generic FF, and also from the model by Martín-Calvo et al. The optimized L-J parameters are summarized in Table S1, where the models are denoted as CO­(U) and CO­(M-C), respectively. The VLEs predicted with these models are shown in Figure S11. The L-J parameters from Dreiding and UFF can be deemed to be comparatively similar to each other. Therefore, as expected, the resulting CO ESP-MM and CO­(U) model yield almost the same predictions, for the binding geometry and energy as well as the relative energy between the “Mg–C–O” and “Mg–O–C” configurations. On the other hand, the parameters used for developing CO­(M-C) are drastically different. The ε value of the oxygen atom is much greater than that of the carbon atom by 6.1 times, whereas the ratio is within a factor of 1.7 for Dreiding or UFF. Interestingly, even with such a different set of parameters, the CO­(M-C) model still predicts a “Mg–C–O” configuration and nearly identical binding energy as that by the CO ESP-MM although it computes a smaller relative energy difference as shown in a. Overall, all of these results again reinforce the importance of developing molecular models with a high accuracy in the ESP representation.

elements.content: As further validations for the CO ESP-MM, we also compute the binding configuration and binding energy of CO in M-MOF-74 (i.e., M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn), which is isoreticular to Mg-MOF-74 but with a different chemical environment. Furthermore, we also investigate the binding geometry of CO in Cu-BTC, a copper-based paddle wheel open-metal-site structure. The binding configurations computed with our model in M-MOF-74 and Cu-BTC are shown in Figures S12 and S13, respectively. The binding energy calculations in M-MOF-74 are shown in Figure S14. Calculations with the models by Sirjoosingh et al. and Martín-Calvo et al. are also included. Overall, our ESP-MM is again able to consistently predict the binding mechanism as reported experimentally and/or computationally. Furthermore, we compute the adsorption isotherms of CO in Cu-BTC at 295 K and all-silica MFI zeolite at 298 K, for which the experimental measurements by Chowdhury et al. and Matito-Martos et al., respectively, are available, and these results can be respectively seen in , parts a and b. Our calculations show a reasonable agreement with the experimental adsorption isotherms provided that the adsorbate–adsorbent interaction has not yet been optimized. We note that the comparison made here is based on the assumption that the experimental sample used for measurements is a fully activated, perfect crystal without defects and/or any inaccessibility regions.

elements.content: We also validate ESP-MMs developed in this study for molecules other than CO. For instance, it has been studied that Fe-MOF-74 with N2O adsorbed is able to activate the C–H bond of ethane and convert it to ethanol. An identification of the binding mechanism of N2O in Fe-MOF-74 would therefore be advantageous for future applications. Experimentally, it has been reported that there are two binding modes of N2O adsorbed in the open-metal site of Fe-MOF-74, η1-O mode and η1-N mode, with probabilities of 60 and 40%, respectively. With our N2O ESP-MM, the binding energies at η1-O mode and η1-N mode () are predicted to be 32.42 and 31.94 kJ/mol, respectively. Per Boltzmann distribution at room temperature, our calculation predicts 55 and 45% probabilities, respectively, similar to the experimental results. Furthermore, we compute the binding geometries of other ESP-MMs in Mg-MOF-74 structures, which show consistent results with the previous DFT study by Lee et al. (). Furthermore, the adsorption isotherms of SO2 in all-silica MFI at 298 K are calculated and compared with the available experimental data by Deng et al. As can be seen in c, the predictions made by the SO2 ESP-MM are in good agreement with experiments.

elements.content: To probe whether these ESP-MMs retain a high fidelity in representing ESP when molecules are in close proximity (e.g., relevant configurations in adsorbed phase and in bulk phase), charge determinations using the same methodology as described above are conducted for dimer structures of several selected adsorbates (i.e., H2S, SO2, and CO2; details can be found regarding their dimer structures in Figure S16). shows that the charges assigned to these molecules in their dimer forms remain essentially the same (i.e., within an average of ∼3% difference). This finding indicates that the assigned charges of our ESP-MMs based on their isolated molecules maintain accuracy in representing their ESPs when they are in a clustered configuration. We also attempted to conduct the same calculations for H2O. Surprisingly, the point charges assigned to the water molecule in a dimer structure are found to be drastically different from those in an isolated form. This is an interesting finding, as it implies that the optimal charges assigned to water could in fact be a strong function of its environment and this factor may be important to consider in the future development of H2O or other molecules for accurate adsorption predictions.

structures in Figure S16).  shows that the charges assigned
to these molecules in their dimer forms remain essentially the same
(i.e., within an average of ∼3% difference). This finding indicates
that the assigned charges of our ESP-MMs based on their isolated molecules
maintain accuracy in representing their ESPs when they are in a clustered
configuration. We also attempted to conduct the same calculations
for H2O. Surprisingly, the point charges assigned to the
water molecule in a dimer structure are found to be drastically different
from those in an isolated form. This is an interesting finding, as
it implies that the optimal charges assigned to water could in fact
be a strong function of its environment and this factor may be important
to consider in the future development of H2O or other molecules
for accurate adsorption predictions.

elements.content: Electrostatic potential optimized molecular models (ESP-MMs) are developed in this study for CO, CO2, COS, H2S, N2, N2O, and SO2, of which gas separation or storage are crucially important in energy- or environment-related processes. These molecular models are developed in a systematic and efficient manner. Specifically, the number and location of massless sites and the point charges are first optimized to best reproduce the ESP surrounding the molecule, computed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Then, the dispersion interaction parameters are fitted to reproduce the experimental vapor–liquid equilibrium. At this step, based on an assumption that the relative magnitude of the Lennard-Jones parameters from generic force fields is sufficiently accurate, two scaling factors are introduced and optimized in order to reduce the overall parameter space. We demonstrated that the developed ESP-MMs from this work are able to accurately reproduce various adsorption properties, as compared to those computed by DFT or measured experimentally. For instance, we showed these ESP-MMs, owing to their reliable description in ESP, can accurately predict the binding configurations of molecules in open-metal-site structures, such as M-MOF-74 (i.e., M = Mg, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn) or Cu-BTC. Furthermore, with ESP-MMs, the predicted adsorption isotherms of CO and SO2 in Cu-BTC or all-silica MFI are also in decent agreement with experimental measurements. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the accurate ESP representations described with ESP-MMs remain the same when the molecules are in dimer configurations. Overall, our results demonstrate the key role of including ESP during the development of molecular models. We anticipate that these proposed ESP-MMs can be utilized to facilitate the future computational discovery and design of nanoporous materials for various applications.

Conclusions
Electrostatic potential optimized molecular models (ESP-MMs) are
developed in this study for CO, CO2, COS, H2S, N2, N2O, and SO2, of which gas
separation or storage are crucially important in energy- or environment-related
processes. These molecular models are developed in a systematic and
efficient manner. Specifically, the number and location of massless
sites and the point charges are first optimized to best reproduce
the ESP surrounding the molecule, computed by density functional theory
(DFT) calculations. Then, the dispersion interaction parameters are
fitted to reproduce the experimental vapor–liquid equilibrium.
At this step, based on an assumption that the relative magnitude of
the Lennard-Jones parameters from generic force fields is sufficiently
accurate, two scaling factors are introduced and optimized in order
to reduce the overall parameter space. We demonstrated that the developed
ESP-MMs from this work are able to accurately reproduce various adsorption
properties, as compared to those computed by DFT or measured experimentally.
For instance, we showed these ESP-MMs, owing to their reliable description
in ESP, can accurately predict the binding configurations of molecules
in open-metal-site structures, such as M-MOF-74 (i.e., M = Mg, Fe,
Co, Ni, and Zn) or Cu-BTC. Furthermore, with ESP-MMs, the predicted
adsorption isotherms of CO and SO2 in Cu-BTC or all-silica
MFI are also in decent agreement with experimental measurements. Furthermore,
we demonstrated that the accurate ESP representations described with
ESP-MMs remain the same when the molecules are in dimer configurations.
Overall, our results demonstrate the key role of including ESP during
the development of molecular models. We anticipate that these proposed
ESP-MMs can be utilized to facilitate the future computational discovery
and design of nanoporous materials for various applications.
